Authors: Arneson A., Wihardini D., Wilson M.
Title: Assessing college-ready data-based reasoning
Source title: Quantitative Measures of Mathematical Knowledge: Researching Instruments and Perspectives
Affiliations: University of California, Berkeley, United States; Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; University of Melbourne, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Arneson, A., University of California, Berkeley, United States; Wihardini, D., Bina Nusantara University, Indonesia; Wilson, M., University of California, Berkeley, United States, University of Melbourne, Australia
Abstract: This chapter advances a definition for “college-ready data-based reasoning�? and describes the development of the Critical Reasoning for College Readiness (CR4CR) Assessment. This assessment has both summative and formative elements, coordinated by an underlying learning progression. Drawing on a literature review on statistics curricula, we have developed (a) a framework for data-based reasoning at the college-entry level and (b) an instrument to measure two of the constructs in that framework: Linking Data to a Claim (LDC) and Formal Inference (FoI). The LDC construct describes student development in thinking about the link between data and the content of a statistical claim, while FoI describes student development in critical reasoning when making formal inference with respect to the notions of practical and statistical significance. Using the BEAR Assessment System (BAS) iterative approach for the instrument development, we found that the developmental progressions defined as FoI and LDC are promising, but that further iterations of the BAS cycle are needed. © 2019 Taylor & Francis.

Authors: Harjanto I., Lie A., Wihardini D., Pryor L., Wilson M.
Title: Community-based teacher professional development in remote areas in Indonesia
Affiliations: English Education Department, Widya Mandala Catholic University, Surabaya, Indonesia; Mathematics Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Berkeley Evaluation and Assessment Research (BEAR) Centre, University of California, Berkeley, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Harjanto, I., English Education Department, Widya Mandala Catholic University, Surabaya, Indonesia; Lie, A., English Education Department, Widya Mandala Catholic University, Surabaya, Indonesia; Wihardini, D., Mathematics Department, School of Computer Science, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia, Berkeley Evaluation and Assessment Research (BEAR) Centre, University of California, Berkeley, CA, United States; Pryor, L., Berkeley Evaluation and Assessment Research (BEAR) Centre, University of California, Berkeley, CA, United States; Wilson, M., Berkeley Evaluation and Assessment Research (BEAR) Centre, University of California, Berkeley, CA, United States
Abstract: The Indonesian government has been struggling to improve the quality of teachers in its public and private schools. Several programmes of teacher education and teacher certification have been designed to enhance teacher quality. However, the programmes do not yet develop effective teachers. Supporting the government programmes, the Tanoto Foundation has facilitated teacher professional development programme since 2010, specifically in elementary schools in the provinces of Riau, Jambi, and North Sumatra. This paper first describes how the Tanoto Foundation has designed and implemented its teacher quality improvement programme for in-service teachers in remote schools in Indonesia and then uses this context to examine to what extent teachers benefited from these programmes. Reported findings broaden our understanding of how teachers can improve their quality via privately sponsored programmes. © 2017 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
Author Keywords: Indonesia; programme evaluation; teacher learning; Teacher professional development
Funding Text 1: This evaluation study was made possible through a grant from the Tanoto Foundation. The authors wish to thank Sihol Aritonang, Ari Widowati, Rahmat Setiawan and the Tanoto Foundation support team as well as the surveyors team led by Frieda Subrata and Risang Rimbatmaja.
Funding Text 2: This work was supported by the Tanoto Foundation.

Authors: Duckor B., Castellano K.E., Téllez K., Wihardini D., Wilson M.
Title: Examining the Internal Structure Evidence for the Performance Assessment for California Teachers: A Validation Study of the Elementary Literacy Teaching Event for Tier I Teacher Licensure
Affiliations: San Jose State UniversityCA, United States; University of California, Berkeley, United States; University of California, Santa Cruz, United States
Authors with affiliations: Duckor, B., San Jose State UniversityCA, United States; Castellano, K.E., University of California, Berkeley, United States; Téllez, K., University of California, Santa Cruz, United States; Wihardini, D., University of California, Berkeley, United States; Wilson, M., University of California, Berkeley, United States
Abstract: Interpretations for licensure tests involve a series of inferences or a validity argument, leading from the test score to decisions about who is accepted or denied entry into a profession. Utilizing an argument-based framework for validation based on the Standards for Educational and Psychological Testing, we explore the evidence for the ongoing use of the Performance Assessment for California Teachers (PACT) for Tier I licensure decisions. The evidence for a unidimensional and a multidimensional structure based on the instrument’s content are examined with an item response model. Examining operational data (n = 1,711) from seven California teacher education institutions, we found sufficient internal structure validity evidence to support the continued, but limited, use of this instrument for its intended summative purpose. Evidence for a three-dimensional structure of model fit better explains overall teacher candidate performance on the PACT instrument as it is currently designed. © 2014 American Association of Colleges for Teacher Education.
Author Keywords: 1999 testing standards; internal structure evidence; item response modeling; multidimensionality; teacher licensure
Funding Details:
